awd_titl_txt: Deterministic and stochastic magnetization dynamics in thin ferromagnetic films and devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Muratov
1313687

     Magnetization reversal in thin ferromagnetic films is often mediated by the appearance and motion of domain walls, which are narrow transition regions separating different magnetic domains.  Under previous NSF funding, the investigator developed a basic mathematical understanding of Neel walls in arbitrary applied fields and 360-degree walls in the absence of the applied fields in uniaxial materials and studied their role in magnetization reversal in ferromagnetic nanorings, both in the absence and in the presence of small thermal noise.  In this project, he further investigates the properties of the domain walls in materials with four-fold magnetocrystalline anisotropy characteristic of materials of technological interest, such as cobalt, and undertakes more detailed modeling, computational, and analytical studies of the magnetization dynamics.  In particular, the new models incorporate spin precession, spin torque, and stochastic effects, as well as the effect of the film topography and polycrystalline structure in as-grown ferromagnetic films.  The investigator develops new numerical and asymptotic tools to tackle the challenges coming from these new aspects of modeling.  As part of the training process, he develops courses in applied sciences and takes part in interdisciplinary training of mathematics and engineering graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs.  The project helps foster closer interactions between researchers in applied mathematics and experimental scientists. 

     Thin film ferromagnetic materials are at the core of a large array of data storage applications of modern digital technology.  The widespread use of these materials is due to their ability to retain information in the form of distinct magnetization states, without the need of being powered, and the possibility to read and write information in a fast and reliable way.  This project is strongly motivated by the efforts to develop a new, universal computer memory based on thin film ferromagnetic materials, the Magnetoresistive Random Access Memory (MRAM).  The investigator addresses the questions of feasibility and reliability of the designs that use ferromagnetic nanorings as storage elements.  Progress on these problems has high potential impact for the computer industry.  In addition, a key aspect of the project is the training of a new generation of applied mathematicians in this highly interdisciplinary area of research.

por.por_cntn:
This project has explored the magnetization dynamics that are exhibited by ferromagnetic materials and devices made of films whose thickness does not exceed a few nanometers. Such materials have been enabled by recent advances in nanofabrication that offer unprecedented spatial resolution down to the scale of tens of atoms.  The greatly improved miniaturization of magnetic devices holds a great promise for an ever increasing density of data storage, a traditional application of magnetic materials since the advent of the computer age. At the same time, a successful design for a new generation of magnetic memory and logic devices is impossible without a deep mathematical understanding of the magnetization dynamics at the relevant spatial and temporal scales.

Mathematical models describing magnetization dynamics in ferromagnetic materials present major challenges in analysis and computations due to their complexity and their multiscale nature. In this project, we took an approach whereby the full micromagnetic modeling framework is replaced by simpler, reduced models by taking advantage of some small parameters inherent in the problem. These reduced models can be simulated much faster, allowing for a greater parameter space exploration. These models are also often amenable to rigorous mathematical analysis, allowing to make precise conclusions about robustness of the behavior of the magnetization.

We have explored several proposed designs of ferromagnetic memory cells and investigated the mechanisms of switching, either due to thermal noise or an applied spin-polarized current, between different data-encoding magnetization states in a device (see the figures for illustrations). On a more theoretical side, we have analyzed the qualitative properties of the special solutions of the giverning micromagnetic equations, including those in the form of one-dimensional domain walls. In particular, we established existence and global stability of Neel wall profiles via energetic arguments, a commonly observed transition layer magnetization profile in ultrathin ferromagnetic films. We have also carried out an analysis of the basic characteristic of the so-called charged domain walls, which is the first analysis of this kind.

More broadly, mathematical models of ferromagnetic materials fall within the category of systems exhibiting energy-driven pattern formation. There, an interplay between short-range attractive and long-range repulsive interactions gives rise to the emergence of spatially modulated patterns. In this project, we have carried out a series of analytical studies of variational problems in which short-range attraction is modeled by a surface energy of the interfaces between two competing phases. A prototypical example of such a system is the celebrated Gamow's liquid drop model of an atomic nucleus, whereby attractive nuclear forces favoring a spherical nucleus are counteracted by repulsive Coulombic forces. The obtained results open up many new avenues of research, both in mathematics and the sciences, as the considered pattern formation mechanism is ubiquitous in many physical, chemical and biological systems of very different nature. The research also exposed a new generation of researchers (2 postdocs and 2 PhD students) to this exciting new area of applied mathematics at the intersection with science and engineering. The mathematical advances under this award also stimulated curriculum development at the graduate level to equip the next generation of applied mathematicians with the tools necessary to deal with the complex interdisciplinary problems of the 21st century.
